description: The ancient sulfur baths of Abanotubani are the heart and soul of Tbilisi, nestled in the oldest district of the city. These natural hot springs, discovered by King Vakhtang Gorgasali in the 5th century, gave Tbilisi its name - derived from 'tbili' meaning 'warm'. The district features distinctive brick-domed bathhouses showcasing a fascinating blend of Persian, Georgian, and Byzantine architectural styles, half-submerged into the ground with their ornate domes visible from the street. For centuries, these sulfur-rich thermal waters have been central to Georgian culture, serving not just as places for bathing but as vital social hubs where important decisions were debated, business deals were made, and communities gathered.
highlights: Natural hot springs (38-40Â°C) rich in sulfur, calcium, magnesium, and sodium with therapeutic properties for skin conditions, joint pain, respiratory health, and circulation
Iconic Chreli-Abano (Orbeliani Baths) with its splendid mosque-like facade decorated with colorful tiles - the most photographed bathhouse in Tbilisi
Legendary founding story: King Vakhtang Gorgasali discovered the hot springs when his falcon fell into them while hunting, leading to the establishment of Tbilisi
Traditional kisa scrub - an exfoliating treatment performed by skilled masseurs using a rough mitt that leaves skin feeling rejuvenated

Historic significance: By the 13th century, there were 65 bathhouses in the district; famous visitors include Alexander Pushkin (who declared them more luxurious than any baths in Russia or Turkey) and Alexandre Dumas
Architectural diversity: from simple brick domes to elaborate entrances resembling richly decorated mosques, reflecting centuries of cultural influences
Choice between communal public baths (gender-separated, budget-friendly) or luxurious private rooms with additional amenities like saunas and massage services
The Royal Apartment at Chreli-Abano features a snow room, Turkish sauna, and private bar for the ultimate luxury experience
tips: Book private rooms ahead, especially on weekends and evenings, to avoid disappointment
Bring your own towel, flip-flops, and swimsuit (though you can be naked in private rooms, swimwear is recommended for the kisa scrub)
Budget 20-40 GEL ($7-15) for shared baths, 70-200 GEL ($25-70) per hour for private rooms
Don't skip the kisa scrub experience - it's a quintessential part of the traditional Georgian bath ritual
Plan for 1-2 hours: one hour is usually sufficient, but book two if you're with a group
Shower thoroughly before entering the bath pools - it's expected social etiquette and local custom for hygiene
Ease into the water slowly as the sulfur baths can be quite hot - allow your body time to adjust to the temperature
Visit Chreli-Abano for the most iconic experience and photo opportunities, but explore other bathhouses like Sulfur Bathhouse No. 5 for more budget-friendly options
The strong sulfur smell is normal and part of the authentic experience - embrace it as part of the historic tradition
Best time to visit is during evening hours when the domed roofs are beautifully lit, creating a magical atmosphere in the narrow streets of Abanotubani
vibe: Ancient, therapeutic, and deeply cultural. The Abanotubani district exudes an atmosphere of timeless tradition where history seeps through the ornate domes and steam rises from centuries-old springs. It's an intimate, communal experience that connects you to Georgian heritage - a place where locals and travelers alike come not just to cleanse their bodies but to participate in a social ritual that has defined Tbilisi for over 1,500 years. The combination of the distinctive sulfur scent, the warmth of mineral-rich waters, the sound of water flowing through ancient channels, and the sight of beautifully tiled facades creates a sensory journey through time. Whether you choose the authentic simplicity of a public bath or the opulent luxury of a private room, you're participating in the same tradition that enchanted poets, travelers, and Georgian nobility throughout the ages.
